newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong Governor's mansion to become guest house.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong Governor's mansion to become guest house.

text.p: Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-hwa, who refuses to move into the mansion occupied by generations of colonial governors because of bad "fung shui", said on Wednesday he would remain in his flat.
Chinese house-hunters traditionally put great store in the principles of geomancy, or fung shui, an age-old belief that harmony with the elements ensures good fortune.

Government House, now occupied by Chris Patten, the 28th and last Governor of Hong Kong, would be converted into a state guesthouse and be used for entertaining by Tung, his principal officials and by local charities, his spokesman said.
Tung was also looking at making part of the mansion into a museum.
He has chosen not to take over Patten's offices in Government House and will move into the nearby civil service headquarters building instead.

"Mr Tung has decided to continue living in his existing apartment ... and not in Government House as he feels that it would be a more appropriate way to mark the beginning of a new era," the spokesman said.
But the taxpayer will foot the bill to lease the flat next door to Tung's and for alteration work to expand his living quarters.
Hong Kong, a British colony since 1841, reverts to China at midnight on June 30.
